messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ikkyudo - Owari Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Cary, I am one of those people!! I will take another look at art and the sword and try and eliminate my preconceptions. A couple of weeks ago I was looking at
messages.messageBody:
Cary,
I am one of those people!! I will take another look at art and the sword and try and eliminate my preconceptions. A couple of weeks ago I was looking at a Nobuie tsuba which was stunning. Mokko form with sukashi axe design. the colour of the iron was incredible.
Anyway thanks a lot for the information.
regards
paul

Cary Condell <condell@...> wrote:
Paul,
Thank you.

Many folks incorrectly limit their understanding
of Owari tsuba to Owari Sukashi tsuba.
In fact, Owari tsuba-ko comprises a great deal
of non sukashi work staring with Nobuie,
Yamakichibei, Hoan, Sadahiro etc.
Best book on the subject is Owari to Mikawa no Tsuba-Ko.

Also check the Art and the Sword, Vol. 3 (1990) pp. 2-53.
A Comprehensive Survey of Bishu Kinko by Wakayama Komatsu.
(Prepared for the 14th NBTHK Zenkoku Taikai (annual convention,10/83)).
Pages 7-8 discusses Fukui Jizaemon. Plate 25 displays a
tsuba by him which has strong affinities to mine.
(Mine is better IMHO).

Regards,
Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com

The Owari tsuba destroyed all of my pre-conceived ideas of what an Owari tsuba looks like. How typical is this style of work?
